data.title: Notifications - show which extension they came from
data.body: Sometimes notification messages appear, and it isn't clear whether they are from vscode or an extension, and if so, which one. Right now I sometimes see "The internet connection appears to be offline" and don't know which extension is responsible. It would be useful to be able to easily trace the message to an extension, maybe with a tooltip on the message that shows the originating extension's name. It looks like a notification UX overhaul is on the way, #1135.

data.title: Leverage configurationDefaults for languages that we bundle with VS Code
data.body:
Now that we support default language specific settings #19733 we should make a pass and leverage this new support for languages we bundle.  

For example:
- yaml -> TAB === 2 spaces
- make -> Do not translate tabs to spaces
- ...

data.title: Exception widget: Enable context menu for the exception message
data.body: Context menu does not appear for the exception widget.

data.title: Revert single change from diff view
data.body: When viewing the diff of a modified file against the most recent repository version, I would like to be able to revert (i.e. `git checkout -p`) individual changes one at a time. For example in WebStorm I can click the little chevrons next to the change to apply it to the other side: This is somewhat related to #10782 on the functionality side and to #5770 on the UI side.

data.title: Exception message text to be selectable
data.body:
Fixes #21083.

Context menu still has to be added. Keyboard shortcut for copying works fine.

data.title: program parameter in launch.json for a node app changes 'commander' to 'command:r' and doesn't find program
data.body:
- VSCode Version:Version 1.10.0-insider
- OS Version:Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

1.hit F5 to launch node program
2.error: 
`Attribute 'program' does not exist ('/home/command:rturner/development/....`
note:  my ubuntu username contains the word 'commander'
launch.configurations has the following entry:

```json
       {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "launch",
            "name": "Launch Program",
            "program": "${workspaceRoot}/Server/Server.js",
            "sourceMaps": true
        }
```

tried hardcoding `${workspaceRoot}` to `'/home/commanderturner/development/`
but same error appeared
If I type `node Server/Server.js` in terminal the program starts fine.
previously this has been working fine, so think it is a recent change to insiders build.

data.title: Editing TSX randomly makes the --type=extensionHost process use 100% CPU
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10-Insiders 0b27b5
- OS Version: windows 10 x64

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/461084/23266094/7f777a96-f9c5-11e6-8f6e-3d51f74acf07.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/461084/23266109/8956f2a8-f9c5-11e6-9636-3f91f116670b.png)

```tsx
import React from 'react'
import {
  View,
  Button,
  TextInput,
  Picker,
  StyleSheet,
  ScrollView,
  Text,
  TouchableOpacity,
  Alert
} from 'react-native'
import t, { FormComponent } from 'tcomb-form-native'
import { KeyboardAwareScrollView } from 'react-native-keyboard-aware-scroll-view'

const Model = t.struct({
  cep: t.String,
  neighborhood: t.String,
  name: t.String
})

const Form = t.form.Form

const styles = StyleSheet.create<any>({
  form: {
    padding: 15
  },
})

export default class extends React.Component<any, any> {
  constructor(props) {
    super(props)

    this.state = this.initialState()
  }

  initialState() {
    return {
      form: {
        cep: this.props.defaultCep,
        name: null,
        neighborhood: null,
      },
      disabled: true
    }
  }

  render() {
       return (
      <KeyboardAwareScrollView style={styles.form} keyboardShouldPersistTaps="always">
        <Form
          ref="form"
          type={Model}
          value={this.state.form}
          onChange={(o) =>{ }}
        />

        <View style={{marginVertical: 30}}>
          <Button title="Cadastrar logradouro" disabled={this.state.disabled} onPress={() => {
            Alert.alert('Sucesso', 'Rua cadastrada')

            this.setState(this.initialState())
          }} />
        </View>
      </KeyboardAwareScrollView>
    )
  }
}
```

Edit `<KeyboardAwareScrollView ` to `<View`, then edit any children (Form, View) leaving the `</KeyboardAwareScrollView>` opened, then change it back to `<KeyboardAwareScrollView`, after a few times, the process will start using 100% CPU. closing the editor won't close the child ` --type=extensionHost` process, and typing on the editor becomes sluggish, all Typescript suggestions stop working

data.title: Toggle Word Wrap should not write to user settings
data.body:
The Toggle Word Wrap action writes `editor.wordWrap` to user settings, but there are multiple issues:

* if the workspace contains a setting for `editor.wordWrap`, the workspace setting will override the user setting. 

* if there is a language specific setting (as we have for markdown), it will override the user setting.

These cases make the action appear as a no-op.

Related: #19842, #20174, #20675

data.title: task spinner in status bar doesn't stop
data.body:
Insiders build.

- open 'vscode' workspace in VS Code
- open Output console for tasks
- run 'Unit Tests' launch config

Observe: after the 'electron' task has finished (and the debug sessions starts), the task spinner in the status bar continues to spin. This spinning continues even after the tests have terminated.

If I run the 'electron' task directly, the spinner stops properly. 

/cc @isidorn @alexandrudima

data.title: Fix for WorkspaceConfigurationService.lookup does not contain value 'null'
data.body: Fixes #21282 WorkspaceConfigurationService.lookup does not contain value 'null'

data.title: Single line code collapsing
data.body:
Currently when you collapse code block you get two lines. Something like this.
```js
get CurrentSession(): DialerCampaignSessionModel {...
}
```
This is quite unreadable when you collaps a lot of blocks and also IMO the whole point of collapsings is to get as few lines as possible. For me, following is much better and more readable.
```js
get CurrentSession(): DialerCampaignSessionModel {...}
```
It will be nice if there was option to select collapsing type. Of course it should work for all languages.

data.title: Suggestions: filterText not easy to use
Javascript Intellisense Often Does Not Work
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.10.0-insider
- OS Version: Windows 7

_I can't reliably determine steps to reproduce._

### Description

Often when I am working on Javascript projects, VS Code's Intellisense does not work. This is usually when I'm working on existing projects - but this is most of the time. Because I'm working on existing projects it's almost impossible to determine what steps are needed to reproduce.

An example here:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/3329959/23265074/9881b254-f9b1-11e6-8dd6-51d27bd9d552.png)

The file is clearly Javascript yet it says "No Symbols Found" and autocompletion doesn't work at all.

Furthermore, I have no errors or any indication of _why_ it isn't working so I'm left pretty much powerless.

2. Open git diff view and commit those changes
3. Notice how the diff view is still open, even though there are no changes
4. Click on the `open file` action in the diff view title bar -> nothing happens

1. Fold a part of code and add a line after this folded part.

data.title: Remove duplicate calls to URI.toString()
WorkspaceConfigurationService.lookup does not contain value 'null'
data.body:
'null' is a valid value for a setting, but WorkspaceConfigurationService.lookup turns it into 'undefined'.

- have the following workspace settings:
```json
{
   "workbench.iconTheme": null
}
```
- set a breakpoint in 'themes.contribution.js' at `this.configurationService.lookup(themeService_1.ICON_THEME_SETTING)`
- the value is
```javascript
{
   ...
   workspace: undefined
}
```

'undefined' should indicate that the setting has not been set in the workspace (luckily it is not a valid configuration value as we only support valid JSON data types)

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Sometimes just open one js file, will infinite show this warning.
2. Screen shot: 
![issue](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/16144833/23263844/64d6f6ee-fa1a-11e6-985d-41055a1355e6.png)
